Package mz

Class WeakHeap

java.lang.Object
mz.SortComparable
mz.Heap
mz.WeakHeap
All Implemented Interfaces:
HeapInterface<Comparable>, Sort<Comparable>, SortSwap<Comparable>
Direct Known Subclasses:
IntroWeakHeap
public class WeakHeap extends Heap
Weak Heap Sort construction uses a buffer that supports constant-time insertion. A new element is inserted into the buffer as long as the buffer size is below a threshold. Once the buffer is full, all the elements of the buffer are moved to the weak heap.
Since:
1.0

  • Constructor Details

    • WeakHeap

      public WeakHeap()
      Weak Heap Sort:
      Construction uses a buffer that supports constant-time insertion. A new element is inserted into the buffer as long as the buffer size is below a threshold. Once the buffer is full, all the elements of the buffer are moved to the weak heap.

      Example:
      1. The root node has no left child
      2. For every node, the value associated with that node is greater than or equal to the values associated with all nodes in its right subtree.
      3. The leaves of the tree have heights that are all within one of each other.
      Note:
      Weak heaps were introduced as part of a variant heap sort algorithm that (unlike the standard heap sort using binary heaps) could be used to sort n items using only O(n log(n)) comparisons. They were later investigated as a more generally applicable priority queue data structure.

      In a weak max-heap, the maximum value can be found (in constant time) as the value associated with the root node; similarly in a weak min-heap, the minimum value can be found at the root.

      Property:
      Worst Case Complexity: O(n log(n))
      Best Case Complexity: O(n log(n))
      Average Case Complexity: O(n log(n))
      Auxiliary Space: O(n)
      Stability: No
      See Also:
      • IntroDPQWeakHeap
      • IntroWeakHeap

  • Method Details

    • heapifyInc

      public void heapifyInc(Comparable[] array, int n, int i)
      heapifyInc method. This method is likely a part of a heap-related algorithm or data structure implementation and is used to maintain the max heap property within a heap structure. It takes an array of Comparable objects, the length of the heap (or array), and an index i as parameters.
      • The @SuppressWarnings("unchecked") annotation is used to suppress compiler warnings related to unchecked type casting when using the compareTo method. This annotation is not directly related to the functionality of the method but rather a way to handle warnings.
      • The method uses a while loop to iteratively perform comparisons and swaps to maintain the max heap property.
      • The loop condition (2 * i) < length checks if the current element i has at least one child within the heap structure. If it does not have a child, it means the element is already in its correct position within the heap.
      • Inside the loop, the variable k is assigned the index of the left child of the current element i (i.e., (2 * i)).
      • The subsequent if condition (k + 1) < length && array[(k + 1)].compareTo(array[k]) > 0 checks if the right child of i exists and is greater than the left child. If so, k is updated to the index of the right child (i.e., k + 1).
      • The next if condition array[k].compareTo(array[i]) > 0 compares the element at index k (the larger child) with the element at index i. If the child is greater, it performs a swap between the elements at indices i and k. After the swap, it updates i to k, allowing the loop to continue the comparisons and swaps downward in the heap structure.
      • If the child is not greater than the current element, the else block is executed, and the loop is terminated using break, as the max heap property is already satisfied.
      heapifyInc method is used to maintain the max heap property within a heap structure by iteratively comparing and swapping elements until the current element is in its correct position within the heap.
      Parameters:
      array - to be arranged.
      n - of the array.
      i - the current element
      See Also:
      • HeapInterface.heapifyInc(Comparable[], int, int)
      • SortSwap.swap(Comparable[], int, int)

    • heapifyDec

      public void heapifyDec(Comparable[] array, int n, int i)
      heapifyDec method. This method is likely a part of a heap-related algorithm or data structure implementation and is used to maintain the max heap property within a heap structure. It takes an array of Comparable objects, the length of the heap (or array), and an index i as parameters.
      • The @SuppressWarnings("unchecked") annotation is used to suppress compiler warnings related to unchecked type casting when using the compareTo method. This annotation is not directly related to the functionality of the method but rather a way to handle warnings.
      • The method uses a while loop to iteratively perform comparisons and swaps to maintain the max heap property.
      • The loop condition (2 * i) < length checks if the current element i has at least one child within the heap structure. If it does not have a child, it means the element is already in its correct position within the heap.
      • Inside the loop, the variable k is assigned the index of the left child of the current element i (i.e., (2 * i)).
      • The subsequent if condition (k + 1) < length && array[(k + 1)].compareTo(array[k]) > 0 checks if the right child of i exists and is greater than the left child. If so, k is updated to the index of the right child (i.e., k + 1).
      • The next if condition array[k].compareTo(array[i]) < 0 compares the element at index k (the small child) with the element at index i. If the child is smaller, it performs a swap between the elements at indices i and k. After the swap, it updates i to k, allowing the loop to continue the comparisons and swaps downward in the heap structure.
      • If the child is not smaller than the current element, the else block is executed, and the loop is terminated using break, as the max heap property is already satisfied.
